Introduction

Respiratory mechanics describe how pressure, volume, and flow are related to each other in the respiratory system.  This article integrates principles of physics and physiology to discuss the interaction between the lungs and chest wall, the process of normal tidal respiration, and the work of breathing.

Lungs and chest wall



The respiratory system consists of the lungs and chest wall, which are considered independent elements because they are anatomically separated.  Changes in the lungs do not affect the intrinsic properties of the chest wall, and vice versa.  However, changes in either affect the entire respiratory system in an additive manner.

Functional residual capacity



The lungs and chest wall have opposing natural tendencies:



  • The lungs have a tendency to recoil inward (collapsing force) due to the elastin content of lung tissue.
  • The chest wall has a tendency to recoil outward (expanding force) due to the curvature of the ribs and intrinsic tension in the intercostal muscles.


The lungs pull the chest wall inward, and the chest wall pulls the lungs outward.  The point where these forces balance each other is the functional residual capacity (FRC) (

figure 1
).  FRC is the natural resting state of the respiratory system in the absence of voluntary effort.  It is equivalently described as the volume of air remaining in the lungs after normal passive exhalation.



Tidal breathing begins from FRC because it minimizes energy expenditure.  Maintaining lung volumes above or below FRC requires additional muscular effort, which can be simulated—holding the breath above FRC requires effort to counter inward lung recoil, similar to keeping a spring stretched out.  Holding the breath below FRC requires effort to counter outward chest wall recoil, similar to compressing a spring.  Pathologic conditions can increase or decrease FRC.  FRC decreases when lung recoil increases (eg, interstitial fibrosis) or when chest wall recoil decreases (eg, pectus excavatum).  Conversely, FRC increases when lung recoil decreases (eg, emphysema) or when chest wall recoil increases (eg, pectus carinatum [rare]).

Respiratory system compliance



Compliance (C) describes how volume (V) changes in response to pressure (P) (ie, C = ΔV/ΔP).  Noncompliant (stiff) objects experience minimal change in volume when pressure is applied.  Normal respiratory system compliance (CRS) is 100 mL/cm H2O (each additional centimeter of water of pressure should inflate the lungs by 100 mL).



Several disease states can alter CRS by affecting the lungs or chest wall:



  • Lung compliance (CL) decreases with interstitial stiffening (eg, pulmonary fibrosis) or alveolar filling processes (eg, pulmonary edema, pneumonia).  It increases with emphysema.
  • Chest wall compliance (CCW) decreases with thoracic cage deformities (eg, kyphosis), arthritis (eg, costochondral joints), extreme obesity, restrictive pleural disease (eg, adhesions, fibrothorax), or rare dystonic drug reactions (eg, serotonin syndrome).  It does not increase.


The relationship between the 3 compliances is as follows:  1/CRS = 1/CL + 1/CCW.

Lung hysteresis



In a pressure-volume diagram, CL is often shown as a relatively straight line with a slope of ΔV/ΔP (

figure 2
).  This line represents inspiration only.  When both inspiration and expiration are graphed, the result is a loop—at a given pressure, the lungs hold more volume during expiration than inspiration (
figure 3
).  This is called hysteresis.



Hysteresis occurs because surfactant spreads out during inflation, reducing its concentration and requiring more pressure to overcome surface tension.  During expiration, surfactant concentration increases again.  The process of hysteresis is somewhat analogous to how memory foam slowly returns to its original shape after being compressed.  Loss of surfactant (eg, in acute respiratory distress syndrome) reduces hysteresis (resulting in a narrower loop) and lowers CL (resulting in a steeper slope).

Tidal breathing



Tidal respiration refers to quiet breathing that occurs under normal conditions.  In adults, normal tidal volume is approximately 500 mL, corresponding to approximately 6 mL/kg of ideal body weight.

Respiratory muscles



  • Inspiration is an active (effort-dependent) process requiring muscular effort.  The primary muscle of inspiration is the diaphragm.  In patients with dyspnea or respiratory distress, accessory muscles of inspiration can be activated; these include the neck strap muscles (eg, sternocleidomastoid, scalenes) and, in extreme cases, additional chest muscles (eg, pectoralis minor, trapezius, latissimus dorsi, serratus anterior).
  • In contrast, expiration is a passive (effort-independent) process that utilizes the natural recoil of the respiratory system.  No muscular effort is typically required.  However, in patients with dyspnea or respiratory distress, accessory muscles of expiration, including the internal intercostals and abdominal wall muscles (eg, obliques, transversus abdominus), may be used.


Greater effort during inspiration shortens inspiratory time.  Conversely, greater effort during expiration does not shorten the expiratory time because the additional force produces dynamic airway collapse, delaying the expiratory airflow.  This can be observed by comparing the time required to exhale all the way to residual volume gently versus forcefully—despite the additional force, the time remains the same.

Normal pressure swings



There are 2 key pressures that govern breathing: the alveolar pressure and the pleural pressure.  These are measured in centimeters of H2O, with atmospheric pressure set to 0 cm H2O by convention.



  • Alveolar pressure (Palveolar):  The pressure inside the lungs.  Air flows from areas of higher pressure to areas of lower pressure.  Inspiratory airflow occurs when Palveolar is negative (eg, −2 cm H2O), creating a gradient between the atmosphere (ie, mouth and nose) and the lungs; conversely, expiratory airflow occurs when Palveolar is positive (eg, 2 cm H2O) (
    figure 4
    ).
  • Pleural (intrapleural) pressure (Ppleural):  The pressure in the pleural cavity (ie, between the lungs and chest wall).  Because the lungs and chest wall are constantly trying to pull apart from each other, Ppleural is always negative (eg, −5 cm H2O).  During inspiration, the diaphragm moves downward, and Ppleural becomes even more negative (eg, to -8 cm H2O), encouraging the lungs to expand.


Transpulmonary (transpleural) pressure (PTP):  The difference between alveolar (ie, inside the lungs) and pleural (ie, outside the lungs) pressure.  PTP is always slightly positive because Palveolar is always higher than Ppleural (even when both are negative).  The positive PTP keeps the lungs inflated against the chest wall throughout both inspiration and expiration.

Disrupted mechanics



As discussed above, the transpulmonary pressure (PTP) is always slightly positive.  Normal PTP = Palveolar – Ppleural = (–2) – (–8) = 6 cm H2O.  Several situations can disrupt this relationship, resulting in PTP that is excessively positive, zero, or negative.

High PTP



An excessively high PTP occurs if Palveolar becomes too positive (↑↑ Palveolar) or Ppleural becomes too negative (↓↓ Ppleural):



  • Palveolar can become too positive during mechanical ventilation (with inappropriate settings), violent coughing, or severe air trapping (eg, asthma exacerbation).
  • Ppleural can become too negative with fibrotic lung disease, causing the lung to retract away from the chest wall.  It can also become too negative during forceful inhalation against a closed glottis (Müller maneuver), as seen in hanging injuries or severe obstructive sleep apnea.


Dangerously elevated PTP (eg, >30 cm H2O) can cause barotrauma such as pleural rupture and pneumothorax, especially if there is underlying weakness of the lung tissue (eg, emphysematous bleb).  Excessive distention of the alveoli can also damage them, causing edema or hemorrhage.



Zero PTP



PTP falls to zero with a spontaneous pneumothorax (eg, ruptured bleb).  This occurs because Ppleural equalizes with atmospheric pressure through the lung defect.  Palveolar also remains at zero because the lung cannot retain volume as air escapes through the hole.  Loss of PTP causes the lung to collapse under its intrinsic elastic recoil.



Negative PTP



A negative PTP occurs when Ppleural exceeds Palveolar.  It occurs in 2 scenarios:



  • Tension pneumothorax:  During standard pneumothorax, Ppleural is zero (ie, atmospheric pressure).  However, in tension pneumothorax, Ppleural becomes positive if air continues to enter the pleural space faster than it can escape.  The high Ppleural compresses the lung and mediastinal structures.  This situation also develops with a sucking chest wound, a type of penetrating chest wall injury that creates a tissue flap allowing air to enter but not escape.
  • Flail chest:  Normally, the ribcage changes position in unison with the lungs, moving outward with inspiration and inward with expiration.  If a section of the chest wall breaks free (eg, ≥3 consecutive ribs are each fractured in ≥2 places), the ribcage paradoxically moves inward with inspiration.  This may cause the Ppleural to become positive with inspiration, limiting the ability of the lungs to fill.


Work of breathing

Resistive and elastic



The work of breathing (WOB) is composed of 2 components, resistive and elastic work.



Resistive work is the energy required to overcome resistance to airflow.  It depends on:



  • Airway resistance:  Mainly determined by airway diameter (resistance ∝ 1/diameter4).  Airway resistance increases in conditions that narrow or obstruct the airway, such as asthmatic bronchospasm and mucus plugging.  Low lung volumes (eg, atelectasis) also increase airway resistance because the airway caliber is reduced.
  • Respiratory rate:  High respiratory rates produce faster airflow velocities, increasing turbulence, fiction against the bronchial tree, and air resistance.


Elastic work is the energy required to overcome the intrinsic elastic recoil of the lungs and chest wall.  Work is required to distend these structures even when flow is absent.  Elastic work depends on:



  • Elastance:  Respiratory system elastance is the inverse of compliance (ERS = 1/CRS).  It is elevated in conditions that decrease CL (eg, interstitial fibrosis, pulmonary edema) or CCW (eg, obesity, kyphosis).
  • Tidal volume:  Elastic work is increased with larger tidal volumes due to the additional recoil of the lung tissue and chest wall as they are stretched.


Optimization of work of breathing



Total WOB is the sum of the energy expenditure of the resistive and elastic components of the respiratory system (

figure 5
).



Humans unconsciously minimize the work required to maintain normal minute ventilation (VE), which is defined as the product of respiratory rate (RR) and tidal volume (VT) (VE = RR × VT).  As outlined above, resistive WOB increases with lower lung volume and higher respiratory rate; in contrast, elastic WOB increases with higher lung volume and lower respiratory rate.  Optimal WOB strikes a balance between these extremes, with RR of 12-14/min and VT of 400-600 mL.  This balance changes with obstructive or restrictive conditions:



  • In obstructive lung diseases (eg, asthma), resistive work is optimized by decreasing airway resistance (eg, bronchodilator therapy) and adopting a slower, deeper breathing pattern to minimize airflow turbulence.
  • In restrictive lung disease (eg, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), elastic work is optimized by adopting a rapid, shallow breathing pattern, which trades greater resistive work (eg, faster airflow) for less elastic work (eg, lower tidal volume).


Normally, not much work is required for tidal breathing (eg, 2%-5% of total basal energy expenditure).  As resistance or elastance increases, greater muscular effort is required to produce the same tidal volume.  For example, in advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), WOB can increase to as much as 30%-40% of total energy expenditure.  This chronically increased energy demand contributes to pulmonary cachexia.  WOB can dramatically increase during acute exacerbations, leading to respiratory failure if patients develop muscle fatigue.

Summary



Respiratory mechanics describe how pressure, volume, and flow change during breathing.  The lungs and chest wall are components of the respiratory system with opposing tendencies: The lungs recoil inward due to elastin, whereas the chest wall recoils outward due to rib curvature.  These forces are balanced at functional residual capacity, the natural resting lung volume after passive exhalation.  Normal tidal breathing involves effort-dependent inspiration driven by the diaphragm and effort-independent expiration driven by natural recoil.  The work of breathing consists of resistive and elastic components.  Resistive work overcomes airflow resistance and is determined by airway resistance and respiratory rate; elastic work overcomes lung and chest wall recoil and is determined by respiratory system elastance (the inverse of compliance) and tidal volume.
